intro: Galium sylvaticum var. pseudoaristatum, commonly known as the false aristotome, is a herbaceous plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, creeping stems that often root at the nodes, forming dense mats. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, elliptical, and often covered with fine hairs. This variant is found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
